John C. Calhoun served as Vice-president for 2 different Presidents John Quincy Adams and Andrew Jackson and clashed with both. Calhoun resigned his postion at the end of Jackson's first term. He is best known as his role in the Senate as a staunch advocate for slavery and Southern political influence. He was one of the three titans of the early 19th century United States Senate. The other two were Daniel Webster and Henry Clay. Those three were the impetus behind the Compromise of 1920 or Missouri Compromise. The principles behind the Compromise were that there would be an equal number of Slave and Free States. Missouri, a slave state was admitted along with Maine, a free state as the newest states in 1820. Except for Missouri, slavery was prohibited North of thr 36′ 30" parallel. John Calhoun was the prototype for the rich plantation owner and White Supremacist Democrat. He laid the groundwork for succession before the Civil War during the Nullification Crisis of 1832. nullification crisis | Summary & Significance Calhoun was effective in politics but I think History will count him among those on the wrong side.
God love him he was a terrible racist, slave owner and trader, but so were many in that time in our country, it’s not like it was particular to him.
